awd_titl_txt: Travel: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2023 ACM Joint European Software Engineering Conference and Symposium on the Foundations of Software Engineering (ESEC/FSE)
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant supports students to travel to the 2023 Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) Joint European Software Engineering Conference and Symposium on the Foundations of Software Engineering (ESEC/FSE). ESEC/FSE is a major conference in the field of Software Engineering. It will be held in San Francisco, California December 3 - 9, 2023.  The travel grant will be used to increase participation of US students. The intellectual merit of the grant is the technical exchange of information and research conversations/collaborations made possible by the conference, as well as advances in the field made possible by these interactions.  The broader impacts stem from education, training and mentoring received by the participants. The international nature of this conference helps develop a globally-aware workforce of researchers and educators within the US and helps build the community of researchers in the field of Software Engineering.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

por.por_cntn:
This project provided travel support to 17 students from 15 US-based colleges and universities to attend the 2023 ACM Joint European Software Engineering Conference and Symposium on the Foundations of Software Engineering (ESEC/FSE). ESEC/FSE is a premier conference in the field of software engineering. It brings together researchers, practitioners, and educators to present and discuss the most recent innovations, trends, experiences, and challenges in software engineering. Since the pandemic, this is the first time ESEC/FSE has been held in the US. This project supported these students, many of whom have not traveled to research conferences since the pandemic, to present their research at the conference, receive feedback from established researchers, develop social skills, and expand their professional network. 

 

Among these students, five of them presented their research at the doctoral symposium, three participated in the student research competition, four presented their accepted papers at the research track, one presented their research at the Journal First track, and one presented their research at the vision track. They also attended many co-located events to network with their peers and leading experts in software engineering. Without the travel support from this project, they would not have sufficient funds to attend ESEC/FSE 2023, present their research, and engage with the research community.

 

These students form a significantly diverse group of students. 11 of the 17 students are from under-represented minority groups. This project advanced their professional development and helped promote diversity and inclusion in the research field. This project has a lasting impact on nurturing student researchers and expanding the U.S.-based software engineering research community. Given the pervasiveness of software in modern society, this growing software engineering research community in the US will strengthen the software workforce by drawing from the full talent pool available and therefore help the nation maintain its competitiveness in the global economy.

 


Last Modified: 01/02/2025
Modified by: Tianyi Zhang
